title: 113_hr5595
content: The "Strengthening Privacy, Oversight, and Transparency Act" or the "SPOT Act" amends the Intelligence Reform and Terrorism Prevention Act of 2004 to include oversight of foreign intelligence activities. It also requires whistleblower complaints to be submitted to the Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board. The Intelligence Reform and Terrorism Prevention Act of 2004 is further amended to allow employees of the intelligence community to submit whistleblower complaints related to privacy or civil liberties concerns to the Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board. The Intelligence Reform and Terrorism Prevention Act of 2004 allows employees to submit whistleblower complaints to the Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board, in addition to other existing laws. This authority is separate from other provisions of law, and actions taken under other laws do not prevent the Board from taking action on the same complaint or information. The Intelligence Reform and Terrorism Prevention Act of 2004 allows individuals to submit complaints to authorized recipients without hindrance. The new subsection defines terms related to congressional intelligence committees and the intelligence community. SEC. 4 amends the Intelligence Reform and Terrorism Prevention Act of 2004 regarding the Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board's subpoena power. SEC. 5 addresses the appointment of staff for the Oversight Board. SEC. 5 amends the appointment process for staff of the Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board in the absence of a chairman. The Intelligence Reform and Terrorism Prevention Act of 2004 is further amended to adjust the appointment process for staff of the Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board. The Intelligence Reform and Terrorism Prevention Act of 2004 is amended to adjust the appointment process for staff of the Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board, with changes to the Executive Schedule. The amendments take effect upon enactment of the Act and apply to new appointments to the Board. Compensation changes are subject to exceptions. The amendments to the Intelligence Reform and Terrorism Prevention Act of 2004 adjust the appointment process for staff of the Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board, with changes to the Executive Schedule. Compensation changes take effect on the first day of the first pay period after the Act's enactment. Existing members have the option to serve full time. The amendments to the Intelligence Reform and Terrorism Prevention Act of 2004 allow current members of the Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board to choose between serving full-time or part-time based on the revised appointment process. The amendments to the Intelligence Reform and Terrorism Prevention Act of 2004 allow current members of the Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board to choose between serving full-time or part-time based on the revised appointment process. Members can elect to serve full-time and begin their full-time service after a specified period following the enactment of the Act. Members of the Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board can choose to serve full-time or part-time after a specified period following the enactment of the Act. The Attorney General must inform the Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board about government activities under the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act of 1978, including providing detailed reports and court decisions.
